lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: We're now in an area where new NFTs are being minted and auctioned.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: sorry, what's an NFT again?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: NFT stands for non-fungible tokens. A single NFT can be a single piece of digital art, that is limited in number and made to be "bought" and "owned" through a cryptocurrency transaction.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: and people go crazy for them!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Yes, the art auction house Christie's recently auctioned their first NFT piece, which was a catalogue of 3D artist Beeple's daily renders, for $69 million.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: and this has led to environmental concerns as well, right? Not just because the transactions are done with cryptocurrency?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: The auctions and minting process are deeply tied into how cryptocurrencies operate. NFTs are generated with a blockchain, just like Bitcoin, which means they're also dependent on the same energy-heavy "proof of work" calculations.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: While some NFT and cryptocurrency systems are trying to find more energy-efficient means of authenticating transactions, established systems like Bitcoin and Ethereum are unlikely to change, due to the investment already made by so many miners.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I think what makes me even more uneasy about this versus something like people throwing out too many cellphones too quickly is that all of this stuff is really invisible.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: bleh, well I think we're almost at the finish line, shall we get out of here?

lines.speaker: Orb
lines.text: EXIT FACILITATED BY TIER 1 NETWORK LOCATION. ACCESS TO TIER 1 FACILITY IN ASHBURN, VIRGINIA AVAILABLE.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: oh, hey, I guess it's been awhile since we heard from you

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: what's that tier 1 stuff?

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: *beeping*

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Did you know? The internet isn't just one network, but a huge, interconnected mess of interlinking networks!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Every ISP is its own network, schools and businesses are often their own networks, as are governments. Technically, even your home is its own network, since it's a collection of devices under the same router.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: But these separate networks can communicate because they all speak the Internet Protocol!

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Tier 1 networks are called the "backbone" of the internet. Most of them use fibre-optic instead of electrical cable, take part in the installation and purchasing of submarine cables, and exchange data between each other at no cost.

lines.speaker: Guide
lines.text: Most tier 1 networks are also ISPs. You probably recognize a lot of these names!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: isn't this a bit of a tonal shift?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: huh, I do recognize a lot of these names, but my ISP isn't on this list.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: wonder how we're getting to my home?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Hop on in, and we'll find out!
